The emissions gap is going to grow in south and southeast asia.
How about placing miniature busts in the men's room?

Paris secured Trump the nomination, baring some other event I cannot imagine.

But if Trump were to win the general, then it occurred to me the party that is destroyed might then become the Democrats. Hear me out here...

Trump gets elected. He has a GOP Congress. He gets them to pass a BIG infrastructure bill, the likes that Bernie is talking about. It gets thru the senate even if the Dems retake the Senate - simply because it is needed.

The infrastructure bill creates millions of jobs, spurs a huge recovery. At that point, the GOP is back in business and off the clowncar track in the minds of the public.

The Dems will maybe have a thin majority in the Senate but shrinking minority everywhere else.

Essentially this scenario has Trump moving the GOP to the left on economic issues and perhaps on cultural issues such as abortion, and the right on immigration. He and they will see him as the new Reagan. It would create a new GOP party that is, overall, to the left of where it now is and outside the clutches of the likes of Koch, I would think.

My main point is if Trump wins and implements a Big Infrastructure project, the Dems will be entering into a new Winter, without having much of a Spring and no Summer under Obama

The pivotal thing is a Big Infrastructure project: whoever implements it gets huge strategic boost

I'm not confident Hillary beats Trump. In the general: she goes to her right, he goes to his left, he'll pick up more votes going left than she going right.

Quite possibly: IIRC, I have made the pitch over the years to various BPEA editors that half the length would produce twice the impact...

Or, perhaps, that more thought should be devoted to making the content properly "stackable"...

Yours,

Brad DeLong

Thanks Brad. I'd like to see some systematic analysis of possible effects of length on impact. It is such a tractable question. Other factors might be more challenging. Isn't it funny (and maybe a bit sad) how trivialities affect important processes?

Cheers,
Grzegorz Jan Ciach

Maybe the BPEA paper was too long? The people that matter obviously have no patience it requires. Also, systematic repetition of the basic message in follow up papers is probably necessary to quickly convince the people that matter of its importance. If you just leave it to natural processes, it might take a generation or two before it sinks in.
so delicious..and this was with no picture!

Trump gives a voice to the populist sentiment against immigrants that has been strong and persistent in many European countries and that led to the defeat of Eric Cantor in his primary in a complete surprise.  In years past, business friendly interests have dominated the Republican coalition - it is not so surprising that another element that has been neglected outside of campaigns would exert dominance for a while, especially when represented by the TV-experienced Mr. Trump.
Teresa: That was the one I was thinking of. Thank you. Old recipe, but aging cook too, I guess, since I was sure it was from the Times and it was only last year. :)  Thanks again, Tom
Tom - America's Test Kitchen had a recipe for a butterflied bird cooked over the dressing.  Very good.
Secret in Their Eyes----yet another inferior remake of a superior foreign-language film.

Julia Roberts has not been a box office force, on her own, since 2001.  While Carol's per screen average was good, it was hardly spectacular, it was half that of Steve Jobs, and look where that film's grosses are now.

"Carol" did more than post "strong results." It's per-theater average was one of the year's biggest. It, not "Hunger Games," was the story of the weekend and Mr. Barnes' dismissal of it as art-house fare suggests that someone else should be reporting the box-office results.  Someone else might also help to clarify why it is that Julia Roberts' legions of fans never seem to turn out to see her movies.  Not all of them have been as poorly reviewed as "Secret in their Eyes."
And don't forget a wealth tax to complement the tax on consumption. In theory, a consumption plus a wealth tax can replace an income tax. the main issue in any tax system is the effective tax rates.

A tablespoon of butter is 1/2 ounce.
So 10 tbs. = 5oz. = 141.747616 gm. Hope this helps.
I agree. More sites now give weight measurements, as they are more accurate. In the meantime, trying googling for conversions for different ingredients. They are out there.

Disappointed that you did not give the amount of butter in grams as you did for the flour. Measuring butter is an impossible task when there is no standardization of measurements. Some recipes call for '1 stick', others for tablespoons. Where I live, recipe quantities are given by weight. Please add gm weight for the butter and then I'll try your 'easy as pie' pie crust recipe.

I think that the inflation target has the meaning of the solemn promise that no anti-inflationary measures will be taken unless inflation settles above this target. It can probably have tangible effect on the inflation expectations.

But the wages cannot be raised by the Fed, sorry. Fiscal measures could help with that, but they would have to be approved by Congress. And they would not, would they?

My Girl Scout experience through the 9th grade was more important in preparing me for life than my college education.  Our troop worked on interesting badges, camped out, spent a lot of time in woods learning survival skills, and was every bit as fun as Boy Scouting. If Girl Scouting has now changed, they should go back to those traditional activities that made Girl Scout experiences so valuable for girls like me.
I dropped out of the Girl Scouts 50 years ago because I refused to be forced to sell cookies. I applaud these girls who want to do something different...
This is just standard roast potatoes. Pretty much goes with every cuisine.

So all that wind derived power won't be exported to either the east or the west grids. Strange, when the interest rate is so low.

Makes me dubious about the supposed advantages of wind turbines.

Still completely wrong.

Some never learn.

Do not deceive yourself that we are being deceived.  What is interesting is why there are those who need to think we are being deceived or misled.  When we say we support Trump, we know exactly what we are saying.

Interesting how GOP supporters have changed their melody. From enthusiastic support for Christie, now all you can do is repeat "Hillary Clinton is Wall Street". Even for a single-issue voter who doesn't care a bit for the environment, for the creation of jobs, the infrastructure, consumer protection, food quality, health policy, inequality or foreign policy, this should not be sufficient to vote for an eventual GOP candidate.
You think the guys polling at 6% (combined!) are the "serious" candidates for the GOP, and everyone else is crazy? Ok then.

Krugman's partisanship leads him to craziness on the Republican issue.

The thing that is fouled up about this campaign is that no one is yet talking about the only issue to be discussed--and one on which the Republicans can and will have a 55%-60% vote in November

Obviously Republicans should have one big issue. "Wages have fallen under Obama, while Wall Street has gotten rich on the basis of the bailout and crony capitalism. He wants immigrants and refugees to keep wages down. Are you better off than you were 4 or 8 years ago? Has Obamacare made health care cheaper and better for you personally--the 85% who are employed and not covered.?

"Hillary is more Wall Street than Obama, and she was co-President when Wall Street got its deregulation than caused this. And she is responsible for the failure in foreign policy."

Obviously the Kochs are financing some crazies as propaganda agents, not serious candidates. They have zero chance. So surely does Trump. The campaign goes from February to June. The serious candidates (Kasich and Christie) will run on the obvious anti-Democratic economic campaign when things get serious.

Krugman is trying to convince the Republicans that their base is so crazy that they must nominate a crazy candidate. What nonsense. And they know it is nonsense. Whether he has convinced himself with his own propaganda is an open question, but readers should not be misled.

Tasty! A great "Surprise Vegetable" for Thanksgiving. But...I had to lower the caloric count, so I replaced the cream with whole milk. Still loved it!

The US has outgrown the power structure created by the Constitution.  Rural interests are grossly over represented in Senate and I would argue that thanks to Republican Gerrymandering also in the House.  This explains why the Sandy Aid bill was defeated originally.  You would think that big business would want infrastructure spending because it would be good for business though but for some reason they don't.

Dr. K,

What you say is correct and Brad Delong's questions, "But why has this lesson not been absorbed by policymakers? It's not as though Krugman (1998) is unknown, or rarely read, is it?" is clearly a critical question for this Century.

It seems to me that the economics community has failed to communicate the insight of your work, or may have failed to see it is in their interest to jump on the Krugman bandwagon.

Changes in "groupthink" at the level you work is historically a challenge. Think of the near disaster of FDR's decision in 1937 based on the conventional economic wisdom of the time, until the right advisor clued in the FDR team on the new theory of JMK.

I don't have to tell you the harm that austerians have done to the World economy. Just think of one of the important factors in the World economy: transportation and the trouble the US has in converting to a more efficient system or even competing more efficient systems like Maglev.

The average annual GWP times 35 years is 5,380 Trillion dollars.

We project that with large scale Maglev implementation, total World transport costs as a share of Word GWP could be reduced from the current 10% with conventional transport systems down to 5% with Maglev (no mechanical friction). Reduction to 5% would save 270 Trillion dollars.

That is why, I am amazed that the US pinches pennies in investing in infrastructure, something that will do a lot of people a lot of good and increase their personal economic benefit.
Gross. Used good mustard and 100% pure maple syrup. Marinade tasted ok... Broiled fish was sickly sweet with no "glazing" effect at all. Also, cooking instructions are confusing.

Perfect! I've been scrambling to use up the tender greens in my garden. Even had two delicata squash and fresh ground ancho chili. Used half a head of radicchio and 1/2 and 1/2 garden greens: arugula and cut-and-come-again salad mix. So my finished salad had a little less bite. But it was a hit! Next time I'll add cubes of a tart goat or sheep cheese. I think it needs that texture and sharpness to round out the sweet, spicy, and sour. And I'll cut the squash into thicker slices.

The aforementioned nonlinearity of the GDP-austerity relationship can explain the difficulties with finding the correct value of the fiscal multiplier. When you apply linear regression to data governed by nonlinear effects, the resulting slope estimates are dependent on the variability range of the independent variable in the data sample you use. The IMF estimates before 2010 were based on data with relatively small range of austerity/stimulus variability. This produced small value of the multiplier. Later, it was increased to 1.5 based on new data with broader variability range. But if you fit a simple parabola to PK's scatterplot, the confusion is clarified immediately. Other ramifications of adopting the nonlinear model would probably also be significant.

Thank you, thank you for the amounts in g & ml!

Sounds great. I calculate nutritional info often with a spreadsheet & ingredient lookups for my diet program (47 lbs since July 2, 2015). I find the net weight loss on cooking is 12.8%, a serving size of 145 g (8 servings), sodium 374 mg & sugars 56 g. Sugar is 33% of recipe; total carb 55%; fat 8.4%; protein 3%. Reducing the sugar will help most in cutting cals but may affect bulking properties of sugar in the recipe.
